One last nit: I'd put a comment here explaining why we double-log. Otherwise, somebody helpful is going to come along and de-duplicate it. :smile:

Won't this kill the test binary anyway?

Yeah.  My mind just didn't want to let it go.  Shall I remove the close?
I don't care so much, doesn't really change anything.
Just question: what does empty media type mean?
I'll set it to json, there's no reason not to here.

Actually this is the override type - that bypasses the behavior of the
serializer itself.  If empty, no override.

comments.body: Why do we need to add this line? IIRC, we enable exp in test/test-integration.sh through KUBE_API_VERSIONS now.

The way it is right now, KUBE_API_VERSIONS just registers the API objects and conversion funcs. Master does not expose the experimental API in apiserver until EnableExp variable here is set to true: https://github.com/kubernetes/kubernetes/blob/master/pkg/master/master.go#L573
Yes. Thank you @nikhiljindal!

diffHunk:
@@ -1,1 +144,148 @@			ExpDatabaseStorage:   expEtcdStorage,
			KubeletClient:        client.FakeKubeletClient{},
			EnableExp:            true,
			EnableLogsSupport:    false,
			EnableProfiling:      true,

comments.body: Godoc
done
Godoc
done
non-todo godoc :)
done
these consts all look specific to your benchmarks.
(so move to that file?)

They're the constants used in managing the rcs used to start pods for tests. The current tests only really want to StartPods, which is a framework call. The framework actually starts up an rc using TestRCManifest. Almost every test needs pods, but requiring them all to hand manage the rc seemed like unnecessary boilerplate so I hid it in the framework.
Suggest not taking an id; everything is run in parallel, there's no ordering.
figured the id would be useful when testing watch/update, since I need some way to get a worker to focus on a subset of a list of pods or their updates will all compete with each other.

Either pass id and take a single function, or take a list of functions and don't pass id. (You already make a unique closure for every function, there's no additional benefit to be had by passing id.) IMO it's super confusing to do both.
That's a good point. I'm passing in a single closure now.
Making a final pass here and I don't understand this line-- why is it necessary?

i want to allow stopping individual components through the same stop method, and don't want to end up closing the stop channel of something multiple times. So i can have;

```
defer master.Stop(all)
```

in every test, and also do:

```
master.Stop(rcmanager)
```

as i please, without having to track exactly what i've stopped along the way in my first defer call. Or did I misunderstand the question?
